docs.abstract: A state judge ruled in favor of Exxon Mobil in a lawsuit claiming the company committed fraud in its accounting for the costs of climate change.
docs.snippet: A state judge ruled in favor of Exxon Mobil in a lawsuit claiming the company committed fraud in its accounting for the costs of climate change.
docs.lead_paragraph: A New York state judge on Tuesday handed Exxon Mobil a victory in the civil case brought by the state’s attorney general that argued the company had engaged in fraud through its statements about how it accounted for the costs of climate change regulation.

headline.main: New York Loses Climate Change Fraud Case Against Exxon Mobil
headline.print_headline: New York Climate Lawsuit Fails As Judge Rules for Exxon Mobil

docs.abstract: The discovery of a wealth of oil in the tiny country, one of the poorest in South America, has deepened ethnic divisions and exacerbated tensions during a crucial election.
docs.snippet: The discovery of a wealth of oil in the tiny country, one of the poorest in South America, has deepened ethnic divisions and exacerbated tensions during a crucial election.
docs.lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Guyana — The discovery of an enormous oil deposit off the coast of Guyana was meant to catapult this tiny country into the top echelons of petroleum producers and put its citizens on the path to better lives.

headline.main: Oil Bonanza Plunges Guyana Into Political Crisis
headline.print_headline: Guyana’s Oil Gusher Fans Political Tensions And Drives Ethnic Rift

docs.abstract: The  findings mark a step forward in using space technology to detect leaks of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from oil and gas sites worldwide.
docs.snippet: The  findings mark a step forward in using space technology to detect leaks of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, from oil and gas sites worldwide.
docs.lead_paragraph: The first satellite designed to continuously monitor the planet for methane leaks made a startling discovery last year: A little known gas-well accident at an Ohio fracking site was in fact one of the largest methane leaks ever recorded in the United States.

headline.main: A Methane Leak, Seen From Space, Proves to Be Far Larger Than Thought
headline.print_headline: Methane Leak, Seen From Space, Proves to Be Far Larger Than Thought

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

docs.abstract: Local governments in California and New York City have sued oil and gas giants. Now Boulder and two Colorado counties have joined the fight.
docs.snippet: Local governments in California and New York City have sued oil and gas giants. Now Boulder and two Colorado counties have joined the fight.
docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, communities suing fossil fuel companies over the costs of climate change have been located on the coasts: cities and counties in California, and New York City. But now, the litigation has jumped inland.

headline.main: Climate Lawsuits, Once Limited to the Coasts, Jump Inland
headline.print_headline: Plaintiffs Far From Coast Sue Over Climate Change

docs.abstract: This largely underdeveloped country on South America’s northern Atlantic coast is the unlikely setting for the world’s next big oil boom. But is it ready to handle the riches?
docs.snippet: This largely underdeveloped country on South America’s northern Atlantic coast is the unlikely setting for the world’s next big oil boom. But is it ready to handle the riches?
docs.lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Guyana — Guyana is a vast, watery wilderness with only three paved highways. There are a few dirt roads between villages that sit on stilts along rivers snaking through the rain forest. Children in remote areas go to school in dugout canoes, and play naked in the muggy heat.

docs.abstract: No one knows for certain how the oil industry will fare in decades to come, but few issues are more important to geopolitics and the planet’s climate.
docs.snippet: No one knows for certain how the oil industry will fare in decades to come, but few issues are more important to geopolitics and the planet’s climate.
docs.lead_paragraph: What is the future of oil?

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

docs.abstract: The giant global oil companies’ cash flow has grown 10-fold in four years, but they are cautious, even anxious, about the future.
docs.snippet: The giant global oil companies’ cash flow has grown 10-fold in four years, but they are cautious, even anxious, about the future.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The good times are back. Or are they? The money is rolling in once again for the international oil giants after a grim period of budget cuts and job reductions following the plunge in oil prices in 2014. The profitability of major oil companies now approaches or, by some measures, exceeds the levels before the crash.

headline.main: The Oil Industry Is Enjoying a Boom, but Will it Last?
headline.print_headline: Oil industry enjoying boom, but will it last?

docs.abstract: Investors are finally paying attention to climate change — though not in the way you might hope.
docs.snippet: Investors are finally paying attention to climate change — though not in the way you might hope.
docs.lead_paragraph: Investors are finally paying attention to climate change — though not in the way you might hope.

headline.main: How Big Business Is Hedging Against the Apocalypse

docs.abstract: New York’s attorney general is about to square off against the oil giant in court.
docs.snippet: New York’s attorney general is about to square off against the oil giant in court.
docs.lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general’s office will take its case against Exxon Mobil to trial on Tuesday, arguing that one of the world’s largest oil and gas companies misled its shareholders and the public by misrepresenting the risks that climate change poses to the value of its oil and gas assets.

headline.main: Did Exxon Deceive Its Investors on Climate Change?

docs.abstract: A 1990s effort to encourage drilling in the Gulf of Mexico has cost the government $18 billion in lost revenue from oil royalties, according to a new report.
docs.snippet: A 1990s effort to encourage drilling in the Gulf of Mexico has cost the government $18 billion in lost revenue from oil royalties, according to a new report.
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States government has lost billions of dollars of oil and gas revenue to fossil-fuel companies because of a loophole in a decades-old law, a federal watchdog agency said Thursday, offering the first detailed accounting of the consequences of a misstep by lawmakers that is expected to continue costing taxpayers for decades to come.

headline.main: Government Loophole Gave Oil Companies $18 Billion Windfall
headline.print_headline: An $18 Billion Loophole Enriches Oil Companies
